journeys.title: Navigating Grief and Loss
journeys.summary: Activities to survive the heavy days, handle triggers, and process grief with gentleness and faith.

milestones.title: Halfway through
milestones.message: You are surviving and healing one day at a time.

missions.title: Survive Today Gently
missions.subtitle: Your First Job Is to Stay Alive and Steady.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Early grief can feel like you’re not only missing someone, you’re missing the version of life you knew.

In this session is not about being strong. It is about surviving with dignity, one hour at a time.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You don’t have to solve your grief today. You only have to hold yourself gently enough to make it through the day.

One small win today is enough: eat, shower, step outside, or call one safe person.

cards.title: Choose Your Hardest Moment
cards.prompt: When does grief hit you the hardest right now?
options: Afternoon when the day gets quiet.
Evening when the house feels empty.
Anytime I hear a song or see something familiar.

cards.title: Your Survival Plan for Today
bullets: Choose 3 anchors: water, one proper meal, one shower, one short walk, one short prayer.
Note down  one sentence: “Right now I feel ______.”
Choose one person you can text: “In this moment is heavy. Can you check on me?”
Before sleep, close with one line: “I survived today and God is still holding me.”

cards.title: A Steady Reminder
cards.text:
Grief doesn’t mean you’re weak.

It means love was real. The goal is not to stop missing them.

The goal is to stop collapsing.

Here’s what it can look like: when your chest tightens after a memory, pause, breathe out slowly, and do one grounding act.

This is how you stay steady.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text:
Father, carry me today.

Help me breathe, eat, rest, and survive with dignity. Hold my heart in Your hands.

Amen.

completionCard.title: You checked in
completionCard.message: Naming it helped you carry it today.

missions.title: Let Yourself Feel Without Drowning
missions.subtitle:
Feelings Are Not Enemies.

They Are Signals.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Many widows and widowers try to stay busy so they don’t fall apart.

But what you avoid will return louder. This time you’ll learn how to feel grief safely without drowning in it.

cards.title: Before You Start
cards.text:
You’re allowed to cry.

You’re also allowed to pause. In this step is about giving your grief a safe container so it doesn’t ambush you all day.

Set a 10-minute timer and let the feelings move through you without judging yourself.

cards.title: Choose Your Fear
cards.prompt: What scares you most about feeling grief fully?
options: I’m afraid I won’t stop crying.
I’m afraid it will feel like the first day again.
I’m afraid people will think I’m weak.

cards.title: The 10-minute Grief Container
bullets: Set a timer for 10 minutes.
During the timer, let yourself feel. Cry, write, sit, breathe.
Write: “What I miss is…” and finish one paragraph.
When the timer ends, stand up and do one grounding action: water, wash your face, step outside.
Tell yourself: “I can feel this and still live.”

cards.title: Why This Works
cards.text:
Structure helps your heart process pain without collapsing.

You’re not shutting grief down. You’re holding it with wisdom.

Here’s what it can look like: when you feel guilty for joy, whisper, “Love and life can exist together.” Then take the next step anyway.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text:
God, help me feel what is real without drowning.

Hold me while I grieve and teach me to breathe again. Amen.

completionCard.title: You honored and protected
completionCard.message: You gave memories a safe place.

missions.title: Name What You Lost
missions.subtitle: Grief Becomes Clearer When You Separate the Losses.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Loss is layered.

You didn’t only lose a person. You lost routines, plans, protection, conversation, and identity. When grief feels like one heavy fog, naming the layers helps you care for the real wound.

cards.title: Ground Yourself
cards.text:
Naming the layers of loss doesn’t increase pain. It gives your pain language, so you stop feeling confused and trapped.

Write three losses: the person, the future you expected, and the daily life you shared.

cards.title: Choose the Sharpest Loss
cards.prompt: Which layer of loss hits you hardest right now?
options: Identity (being a spouse, being known deeply).

cards.title: Do the Grief Inventory
bullets: Write five sentences, one for each layer you chose and the next four you still feel.
For each sentence, add: “What I miss most is…”
Circle the sentence that makes you tear up the most.
Answer: “What do I need right now because of this loss?” (rest, support, structure, prayer, conversation).
Pick one care action that matches that need and do it today.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text: When you only say “I’m sad,” your body holds vague pain all day. When you name what you lost, your heart starts processing instead of panicking.

completionCard.title: You prepared
completionCard.message: A plan helps you feel safer.

missions.title: Create a Grief Routine
missions.subtitle: Structure Makes Grief Less Chaotic.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Grief can feel unpredictable.

Some hours are calm, then one memory knocks you down. A simple routine won’t erase grief, but it reduces emotional ambush. Today you will build a daily rhythm that supports your healing.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Routine doesn’t mean you’re moving on.

It means you’re choosing stability while you heal.

Choose one anchor for morning, one for afternoon, one for evening.

Keep it simple.

cards.title: Pick Your Hardest Time of Day
cards.prompt: When does your grief feel most unmanageable?

cards.title: Build Your 3-part Routine
bullets: Choose 1 morning anchor (water, prayer, stretch, sunlight).
Choose 1 midday anchor (one meal, one message to someone safe, one 10-minute walk).
Choose 1 evening anchor (shower, tea, worship music, journaling, early bedtime).
Write your anchors on a note where you can see them.
Commit to doing these anchors for 7 days, even if your feelings change.

cards.title: Keep This in Mind
cards.text:
In grief, motivation comes and goes.

Anchors help you care for yourself even when you feel numb.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text:
God, help me create rhythms that support my healing.

Teach me to live one steady day at a time. Amen.

missions.title: Handle Waves of Sadness
missions.subtitle:
Waves Are Normal.

They’re Not Setbacks.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Grief comes in waves.

You can be okay, then suddenly you’re not. Many people panic when the wave hits and think they’re failing.

This activity teaches you how to ride a wave without drowning.

cards.title: Take a Deep Breath
cards.text:
A wave is a surge of emotion.

It will rise, peak, and fall. Your job is to stay present and safe while it passes.

When the wave hits, breathe out for 6 and name what you feel: sad, angry, scared, empty.

cards.title: Choose What Your Wave Looks Like
cards.prompt: When grief hits suddenly, what usually happens?
options: I replay memories and panic loop.

cards.title: Use the Wave Method
bullets: W - Watch: name it: “This is a grief wave.”
A - Allow: stop fighting it for 60 seconds. Breathe.
V - Vent safely: cry, write, or talk to God out loud.
E - Exit gently: do one grounding act (wash your face, step outside, sip water).
After the wave, write one sentence: “I survived the wave.”

cards.title: A Calm Note
cards.text: Waves feel like they will last forever, but they don’t. The more you practice riding them, the less afraid you become of your own emotions.

missions.title: Carry the Memories with Peace
missions.subtitle: Memories Can Comfort You or Crush You.
missions.whyThisMatters: Memories are sacred, but they can also trigger deep pain. Today you will choose a healthier relationship with memories so they become part of your healing, not your undoing.

cards.title: Start Gently
cards.text:
You don’t have to delete memories to heal.

You just need to hold them in a way that doesn’t break you.

Pick one memory and write one sentence of gratitude and one sentence of pain.

Both can exist.

cards.title: Choose Your Memory Pattern
cards.prompt: What do memories do to you most often?
options: They comfort me, then I crash.
They make me feel guilty for living.
They trigger anger about what happened.
They make me wish I could go back.

cards.title: Create a Memory Boundary
bullets: Pick one memory that is both beautiful and painful.
Write: “What this memory shows me about our love is…”
Write: “What this memory makes me fear is…”
Set a boundary: choose a time limit (5 minutes) or a ritual (look, thank God, then stop).
Choose one comforting act afterward: music, prayer, a walk, or calling someone safe.

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text:
Memories are not a trap.

They are proof of love. Your healing is learning how to remember without losing yourself.

missions.title: Stop Blaming Yourself
missions.subtitle: Self-blame Keeps Grief Stuck.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Many widowed people replay what they could have done differently: signs missed, words not said, actions not taken.

Self-blame feels like control, but it becomes punishment. Today you will release the burden you were never meant to carry.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You can miss them deeply and still forgive yourself.

Love does not require punishment.

Write the guilt sentence, then answer it with one truth: “I did my best with what I knew.”

cards.title: Choose Your Self-blame Sentence
cards.prompt: Which thought comes up most often?
options: If I had acted sooner, they might still be here.
I regret what I said or didn’t say.
I feel responsible for the outcome.

cards.title: Do the Truth Release
bullets: Write your self-blame sentence exactly as it comes.
Write the facts: what was in your control and what wasn’t.
Write one compassionate sentence to yourself: “I did what I could with what I knew.”
Write what you would tell a friend in the same situation.
Speak that same kindness to yourself out loud.

cards.title: A Wiser View
cards.text: Self-blame keeps you connected to a fantasy that you had total power. The truth is harder, but kinder: you are human, and life is fragile.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text:
Father, help me release self-blame.

Cover my heart with mercy. Teach me to rest in Your kindness.

Amen.

completionCard.title: You helped your body
completionCard.message: Your body got a little relief.

missions.title: Invite Support Without Shame
missions.subtitle: You Weren’t Meant to Carry This Alone.
missions.whyThisMatters: Grief can isolate you. People may not know what to say, and you may not know what to ask for. Today you will request support clearly so you don’t suffer in silence.

cards.title: Ground Yourself
cards.text:
Asking for support is not weakness.

It is wisdom. You’re allowed to need people.

Send one message today: “Can you check in on me this week?”

cards.title: Choose the Support You Need
cards.prompt: What kind of support would help you most right now?
options: Someone to talk to once a week.
Help with meals or household tasks.

cards.title: Make the Ask
bullets: Choose one person who feels safe.
Send a clear request: “Can you ______ this week?”
Give two options for time or help (example: “Tuesday or Thursday?”).
If they can’t, ask a second person instead of shutting down.
After you ask, write: “I am not a burden. I am human.”

cards.title: A Steady Reminder
cards.text:
Most people want to help but need direction.

Your clarity gives them a way to show love.

missions.title: Honor Your Love Without Stopping Life
missions.subtitle: You Can Honor Love and Still Live.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Some widowed people fear that healing means forgetting.

Others fear that living again means betrayal. Today you will build an honoring ritual that keeps your spouse’s memory meaningful while you keep moving forward.

cards.title: Start Gently
cards.text:
Healing is not erasing. Healing is carrying love with dignity while you continue living.

Honor love with one act: a prayer, a candle, or sharing one story with someone safe.

cards.title: Choose Your Fear
cards.prompt: Which fear feels most true for you?
options: If I laugh again, it means I’m moving on.
If I date again, people will judge me.
If I build a future, it means I forgot them.
If I feel joy, it dishonors our love.
If I stop crying, it means love was not real.

cards.title: Create an Honoring Ritual
bullets: Choose one honoring act: speak their name in prayer, visit a meaningful place, keep a gratitude journal, or do an act of kindness in their memory.
Choose one living act: meet a friend, start a routine, take a class, serve at church.
Write: “Honor looks like ______. Living looks like ______.”
Repeat this ritual once a week for 4 weeks.
Notice how your heart changes over time.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Love is not proved by staying broken.

Love is proved by how you carry it with dignity. God is not asking you to stop living.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text:
God, help me honor my spouse with gratitude, not guilt.

Give me permission to live again with peace. Amen.

missions.title: Take Your Next Small Step
missions.subtitle: Healing Is Built One Step at a Time.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Big decisions can feel impossible in grief.

But small steps build momentum. Today you will choose one next step that makes life feel slightly more stable.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You don’t need a five-year plan.

You need one next step that supports your life right now.

Choose one next step and schedule it within 24 hours.

Small steps rebuild life.

cards.title: Choose Your Next Step Area
cards.prompt: Which area needs one small step this week?

cards.title: Do the Next Step Plan
bullets: Choose one area and write one specific step.
Make it small enough to do in 30 minutes.
Schedule it for a time you’ll realistically keep.
After you do it, write: “I moved forward today.”
If you miss it, reschedule instead of shaming yourself.

cards.title: A Calm Note
cards.text:
Small steps feel too small until they add up.

Healing is often quiet, not dramatic.

journeys.title: Supporting Kid(s) Through Grief
journeys.summary: Activities to help your kid(s) feel safe, talk about feelings, and grieve with support and stability.

milestones.title: Halfway through
milestones.message: You are giving your kid(s) safety through grief.

missions.title: Regulate Your Body First
missions.subtitle: Your Body Holds Grief Too.
missions.whyThisMatters: When grief hits, your body can stay tense for months. Many people try to heal emotionally while ignoring physical stress. This time you’ll calm your nervous system so your mind can breathe.

cards.title: Take a Deep Breath
cards.text: If your body is constantly tense, your mind will stay anxious. Right now you’ll regulate your body so you can think clearly and rest better.

cards.title: Choose Your Symptom
cards.prompt: What shows up most in your body lately?

cards.title: 5-minute Regulation
bullets: Put one hand on your chest and one on your stomach.
Breathe in slowly for 4, breathe out for 6. Repeat 10 times.
Relax your shoulders and unclench your jaw.
Drink water after.
Note down  one line: “My body is safe enough to rest.”

cards.title: What This Changes
cards.text:
Regulation doesn’t remove grief.

It helps you carry grief without panic. This is how you build emotional stability day by day.

Here’s what it can look like: when you feel guilty for joy, whisper, “Love and life can exist together.” Then take the next step anyway.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text:
Father, calm my body and mind.

Help me breathe deeply and rest. Give me stability even in grief.

Amen.

completionCard.title: You checked in
completionCard.message: That question gave your kid(s) safety.

missions.title: Create a Calm Morning
missions.subtitle: Your Mornings Set the Tone for Your Whole Day.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Many widowed people wake up and feel the loss immediately.

The brain searches for what used to be normal. Today you will build a calm morning sequence so grief doesn’t control your entire day before you even start.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
A calm morning won’t remove grief, but it reduces shock.

Your body learns: I can start this day slowly.

cards.title: Choose Your Morning Struggle
cards.prompt: What is hardest about mornings right now?
options: I wake up and feel numb.
I wake up and cry immediately.
I wake up and feel angry.
I wake up and feel empty and stuck.

cards.title: Your 12-minute Morning Sequence
bullets: Minute 1: Sit up and take 6 slow breaths.
Minute 2-4: Drink water and open a window for fresh air.
Minute 5-7: Read one verse or Psalm line (Psalm 23 or Psalm 34:18).
Minute 8-10: Write one sentence: “Today I need ______.”
Minute 11-12: Choose one simple task you will finish before noon.
Repeat for 7 days. Keep it simple.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Your brain is adjusting to a new reality.

Routines teach your mind safety and reduce morning dread.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text:
Father, help me start my day with steadiness.

Give me strength for the next few hours. Amen.

missions.title: Stop the Mental Replay
missions.subtitle: Rumination Keeps Grief Sharp and Exhausting.
missions.whyThisMatters: When you replay the loss, the last moments, or the “what if” questions, your body reacts as if it is happening again. Today you will interrupt replay gently and redirect your mind without denying your grief.

cards.title: Take a Deep Breath
cards.text:
Mental replay is your brain trying to make sense of what happened.

The problem is it traps you in pain. Today you’ll learn an interrupt and redirect skill.

cards.title: Choose Your Replay Theme
cards.prompt: What does your mind replay most often?
options: The last conversation or last day.
How it happened and what I could have changed.
The life we planned that won’t happen.

cards.title: Use the 3-step Interrupt
bullets: Step 1: Name it: “This is replay.”
Step 2: Ground: press your feet into the floor and breathe out slowly for 6.
Step 3: Redirect: choose one anchor sentence: “Right now I am safe.” or “This thought is pain, not prophecy.”
Then do one action that uses your hands: wash dishes, fold clothes, tidy one corner, or take a short walk.
Later, schedule 10 minutes to write what your replay is trying to protect you from.

cards.title: A Wiser View
cards.text:
You can honor your grief without feeding your replay.

The goal is not to control thoughts. The goal is to stop letting thoughts control you.

missions.title: Hold Your Anxiety Gently
missions.subtitle: Anxiety After Loss Is Normal and Treatable.
missions.whyThisMatters: After losing someone, your sense of safety can collapse. Anxiety can show up as fear, racing thoughts, or tightness in your chest. Today you will soothe anxiety without shame and without pretending you’re okay.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Anxiety is your body saying: something bad happened, so I must stay alert.

Today you’ll teach your body: we can relax again.

cards.title: Choose Your Anxiety Signal
cards.prompt: How does anxiety show up in you most often?

cards.title: The 5-4-3-2-1 Calm Reset
bullets: Name 5 things you can see.
Name 4 things you can feel (chair, clothing, feet).
Name 3 things you can hear.
Name 2 things you can smell.
Name 1 thing you can taste.
Then speak: “I am here. I am safe enough for this moment.” Do this once in the morning and once at night for 3 days.

cards.title: A Calm Note
cards.text:
Anxiety often means your body is grieving too.

When you calm your body, your mind follows.

missions.title: Break the Isolation Cycle
missions.subtitle: Isolation Feels Safe, but It Increases Pain.
missions.whyThisMatters:
After loss, you may avoid people because you don’t want pity or awkward questions.

But isolation gives grief too much room. Today you will choose connection without forcing yourself into exhausting social spaces.

cards.title: Ground Yourself
cards.text: You don’t need crowds. You need one or two safe connections that keep you from disappearing.

cards.title: Choose Your Isolation Pattern
cards.prompt: How do you isolate most often?
options: I cancel plans and stay home.
I scroll online instead of connecting.
I only talk when people call me first.
I pretend I’m fine so people stop asking.

cards.title: Create a Connection Plan
bullets: Choose one safe person and one safe place (church group, friend’s home, short walk).
Send a message: “Can we talk this week?” or “Can we take a short walk?”
Set a time limit for the interaction (30-60 minutes).
After, journal: “What helped? What drained me? What I want next time is…”
Repeat once this week. Keep it small.

cards.title: Keep This in Mind
cards.text:
Connection doesn’t remove grief.

But it reduces the weight of carrying it alone.

missions.title: Handle Unexpected Triggers
missions.subtitle: Triggers Are Predictable, Even When They Feel Sudden.
missions.whyThisMatters: A smell, song, picture, or place can hit you so hard you feel pulled back into the loss. Today you will plan for triggers so they don’t ruin your entire day.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Triggers are not proof you’re failing.

They are reminders that love was real. Planning reduces panic.

cards.title: Choose Your Most Common Trigger
cards.prompt: What triggers you most often?
options: Places you used to go together.

cards.title: Make Your Trigger Plan
bullets: Write your top 3 triggers.
For each trigger, write: “When this happens, I will ______.”
Choose 1 grounding action (breathe, step outside, call someone, pray).
Choose 1 comfort action (music, tea, shower, journaling).
Save the plan on your phone so it’s ready when the trigger comes.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Planning is not fear.

Planning is love for yourself. It keeps one moment from destroying a whole day.

missions.title: Stop Living in Survival Mode
missions.subtitle: Survival Mode Keeps You Exhausted.
missions.whyThisMatters: Grief can push you into a constant state of alertness: always bracing for more loss. Today you will notice survival mode and begin creating a life that includes rest, not only endurance.

cards.title: Start Gently
cards.text:
Survival mode says: don’t feel, just get through.

Healing says: you can rest, and you can feel.

cards.title: Choose Your Survival Sign
cards.prompt: Which sign shows you are in survival mode?
options: I stay busy to avoid feelings.
I’m always tired but can’t rest.

cards.title: Build One Rest Boundary
bullets: Choose one rest boundary for today: no late-night scrolling, early bedtime, or one hour of quiet.
Choose one nourishing action: meal, walk, sunlight, or worship music.
Write: “Rest is not laziness. Rest is part of healing.”
Do your rest boundary today and notice how your body responds.

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text: Your body cannot heal while constantly bracing. Rest is how you tell your nervous system it is safe enough to breathe again.

missions.title: Build New Routines
missions.subtitle: Your Home Needs New Rhythms.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Your routines used to include your spouse.

Now every small habit can remind you of what changed. Today you will build new routines that respect your grief and support your stability.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
New routines don’t erase the old ones.

They simply help you live with the new reality.

cards.title: Choose What Routine Hurts Most
cards.prompt: Which routine feels most painful now?

cards.title: Create One New Routine
bullets: Pick one painful routine and change one part of it.
Example: eat with music on, change seating, invite a friend once a week, or eat earlier.
Write the new routine in one sentence.
Try it today and journal: “What felt better? What still hurt?”
Keep what helps and adjust what doesn’t.

cards.title: A Steadier Lens
cards.text:
Small changes reduce the sting.

They help your brain stop expecting the old life to return.

missions.title: Ask for Help Clearly
missions.subtitle: People Want to Help, but They Need Direction.
missions.whyThisMatters: After loss, many people say “Let me know if you need anything,” and you don’t know what to say. Today you will make one clear, specific request so you’re supported practically and emotionally.

cards.title: Ground Yourself
cards.text:
Needing help is not failure.

It is part of being human. Today you’ll practice clarity.

cards.title: Choose What Help Would Relieve You Most
cards.prompt: What kind of help would lighten your load right now?

cards.title: Make One Clear Request
bullets: Choose one person you trust.
Send one specific request: “Can you ______ on ______?”
Give a time option: “Tuesday or Thursday?”
If they say no, ask someone else instead of retreating.
After you ask, write: “I deserve support.”

cards.title: A Calm Note
cards.text:
Clear requests prevent disappointment.

People cannot support what they do not understand.

missions.title: Choose Hope Without Pressure
missions.subtitle: Hope Does Not Mean Pretending You’re Okay.
missions.whyThisMatters: Some people weaponize hope: “Be strong, God is good, you’ll be fine.” That can feel painful. Today you will define hope in a way that honors grief and still gives you direction.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Christian hope is not denial.

It is trust in God even when your heart aches.

cards.title: Choose What Hope Feels Like to You
cards.prompt: Which definition of hope fits you right now?
options: Hope is making it through today.
Hope is believing I won’t always feel this way.
Hope is trusting God with my future.
Hope is allowing joy again without guilt.
Hope is staying connected instead of hiding.

cards.title: Write Your Hope Statement
bullets: Finish: “Hope for me right now is ______.”
Finish: “One thing I can do this week that reflects hope is ______.”
Choose one action and schedule it.
Write one verse or promise that strengthens you (Psalm 34:18, Isaiah 41:10).
End by speaking: “God is with me, even here.”

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text: Hope is not a mood. It’s a decision to take the next step with God, even while grieving.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text:
Father, teach me hope that doesn’t deny pain.

Give me strength for the next step. Amen.

completionCard.title: Journey complete
completionCard.message: You supported your kid(s) with stability and love.

journeys.title: Rebuilding Life After Loss
journeys.summary: Activities to rebuild routines, manage loneliness, and find purpose again without rushing your healing.

milestones.title: Halfway through
milestones.message: You are becoming stronger and steadier.

missions.title: You Are Still Here
missions.subtitle: Loss Changed You, but It Did Not Erase You.
missions.whyThisMatters: After losing a spouse, many people feel like they lost themselves too. In this moment you will separate grief from identity and remember: you are still a whole person who can live again.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You are not only someone who lost.

You are someone who loved deeply. In this session you’ll hold both truths with dignity.

cards.title: Choose Your Biggest Identity Struggle
cards.prompt: Which one feels most true lately?
options: I don’t know who I am without them.
I feel afraid of the future.

cards.title: Write Your Identity Truth
bullets: Finish: “I am still ______.” (a mother, a man of faith, a woman of strength, a person with purpose).
Finish: “I am allowed to ______.” (laugh again, build again, be supported).
Journal  one small identity action you’ll do today: groom yourself, go outside, join community, call a friend.
Finish with: “Love ended, but my life did not end.”

cards.title: A Quick Truth
cards.text:
Grief will try to make your life small because it feels safer.

But smallness can become a prison. Healing includes slowly expanding your life again. example: when you feel guilty for joy, whisper, “Love and life can exist together.” Then take the next step anyway.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text:
Father, remind me that I still belong here.

Give me strength to live again with dignity and faith. Amen.

completionCard.title: You rebuilt stability
completionCard.message: That routine helped your day feel safer.

missions.title: Stop Shrinking Your Life
missions.subtitle: Smallness Can Feel Safe, but It Becomes a Prison.
missions.whyThisMatters: After loss, many people shrink their life: fewer places, fewer people, fewer risks. It feels protective, but it can quietly become isolation and fear. Today you will notice where you’ve shrunk and take one gentle step outward.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Shrinking is understandable.

But your life is still worth living. Today you will expand one small area without forcing a big leap.

cards.title: Choose Where You’ve Shrunk
cards.prompt: Where have you noticed yourself pulling back most?
options: Joy (I feel guilty when I enjoy anything).

cards.title: Expand One Small Area
bullets: Write one sentence: “I have been shrinking in ______.”
Pick one small expansion step you can do within 48 hours (attend church quietly, visit a friend, sit in a café for 20 minutes).
Set a time and commit to it.
After you do it, journal: “What was hard? What surprised me? What helped?”
Repeat one expansion step weekly for one month.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text: You don’t expand by waiting to feel ready. You expand by taking small steps and letting confidence grow after action.

missions.title: Release Guilt and Second-guessing
missions.subtitle: Guilt Often Disguises Itself as Love.
missions.whyThisMatters: After loss, guilt can become a constant companion. You may replay what you should have done, what you could have said, or what you didn’t notice. Today you will separate guilt from love and replace it with compassion and truth.

cards.title: Take a Deep Breath
cards.text:
Guilt promises control: “If I blame myself, I can make sense of this.” But it becomes a heavy chain.

Today you’ll loosen that chain.

cards.title: Choose Your Guilt Theme
cards.prompt: Which type of guilt is strongest for you?
options: Guilt about not seeing the signs.

cards.title: Do the Guilt Split
bullets: Write the guilt sentence exactly as it comes.
Split the page into two columns:
Column A: “What I controlled.” Column B: “What I did not control.”
Write a compassionate response as if you were speaking to your best friend.
Speak one line out loud: “I did what I could with what I knew.”
If guilt returns today, repeat that line instead of replaying the blame.

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text:
Love is not proven by guilt.

Love is proven by gratitude and honor. Mercy is what allows you to breathe again.

missions.title: Let People See You
missions.subtitle: Healing Requires Safe Visibility.
missions.whyThisMatters:
After becoming widowed, it can feel like people only see your loss, not you.

Or you may hide because you don’t want to cry in public. Today you will practice safe visibility: letting trusted people see you without performing strength.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text: Being seen does not mean being exposed. It means choosing one safe person and letting them witness you honestly.

cards.title: Choose Your Fear About Being Seen
cards.prompt: What makes it hardest to let people in?
options: I don’t want to cry in public.
I feel ashamed of my loneliness.
I’m afraid people will move on quickly.

cards.title: Practice Safe Visibility
bullets: Choose one safe person (friend, mentor, church leader).
Send one sentence: “I don’t need advice. I just need presence.”
Plan one meeting or call within 7 days.
During the conversation, share one honest feeling without minimizing it.
Afterward, write: “Being seen did not destroy me.”

cards.title: Keep This in Mind
cards.text:
Isolation often grows because you keep trying to protect others from your pain.

Safe people can hold it with you.

missions.title: Rebuild Confidence Slowly
missions.subtitle: Confidence After Loss Is Rebuilt, Not Found.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Grief can make you doubt your ability to lead your life.

You may feel behind, unprepared, or fragile. Today you will rebuild confidence through small wins, not pressure.

cards.title: Start Gently
cards.text:
Confidence is not a feeling you wait for.

It is the result of keeping small promises to yourself.

cards.title: Choose Your Confidence Gap
cards.prompt: Where do you feel least confident right now?

cards.title: Create 3 Small Wins
bullets: Write 3 small tasks you can complete today (laundry, meal, short walk, call a friend).
Choose the easiest one and do it first.
After each task, say out loud: “I can still lead my life.”
At night, list the wins, even if they were small.
Repeat for 3 days.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text: When grief makes you feel powerless, small wins quietly restore your sense of agency.

missions.title: Find Your New Purpose
missions.subtitle: Purpose Returns When You Take Meaningful Steps.
missions.whyThisMatters: Purpose after loss can feel impossible because your life was intertwined. But purpose can be rediscovered through values, service, and community. Today you will identify a purpose thread you can follow gently.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Purpose does not appear as a sudden feeling.

It grows when you align your actions with your values.

cards.title: Choose Your Purpose Thread
cards.prompt: Which thread feels most meaningful to you right now?

cards.title: Follow One Thread
bullets: Write one sentence: “My life still stands for ______.”
Write one action that expresses this value this week.
Make the action small and doable (help one person, volunteer once, call family).
Schedule it.
After you do it, journal: “What did I feel? What did I learn?”

cards.title: A Steadier Lens
cards.text:
Purpose helps grief have a place to go.

It doesn’t erase loss, but it gives your life direction again.

missions.title: Honor Your Marriage Without Living Backward
missions.subtitle: Honor Is Gratitude, Not a Life Sentence.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Some people stay stuck because they believe living forward dishonors their marriage.

But honor and movement can coexist. Today you will define what honoring your spouse looks like while still allowing yourself to grow.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You can honor your spouse and still build a future.

Honor is not staying frozen. Honor is carrying love well.

cards.title: Choose What Keeps You Stuck
cards.prompt: What keeps you from moving forward most?
options: Feeling like I’m leaving them behind.
Feeling like life has no meaning without them.

cards.title: Define Honor and Movement
bullets: Write: “Honoring my spouse looks like…” (gratitude, remembering, living with integrity).
Write: “Moving forward looks like…” (routines, friendships, service, purpose).
Pick one honoring act you’ll do this month.
Pick one forward act you’ll do this week.
Close with: “My love is honored. My life is allowed.”

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text:
The person you loved would not want your life to end emotionally.

Healthy honor includes healing.

missions.title: Reconnect with God Honestly
missions.subtitle: Faith After Loss Must Be Honest to Be Real.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Loss can make prayer feel difficult.

You may feel distant, angry, or numb. Today you will reconnect with God through honesty instead of performance.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
God can handle your questions.

You don’t need perfect words. You need truth.

cards.title: Choose What Your Faith Feels Like
cards.prompt: What is your current spiritual struggle?
options: I feel confused about God’s plan.

cards.title: Pray with Honesty
bullets: Write one honest paragraph to God: “Lord, this is where I am…”
Read Psalm 13 or Psalm 34: 18 slowly.
Underline one line that speaks to your pain.
Write one request: “God, I need ______.”
Sit in silence for 2 minutes, breathing slowly.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Faith isn’t pretending you’re okay.

Faith is returning to God with your real heart.

missions.title: Create Your New Identity Statement
missions.subtitle: Words Shape How You Carry Your Future.
missions.whyThisMatters:
After loss, it’s easy to let “widow” or “widower” become your only identity.

But you are more than your loss. Today you will write an identity statement that honors grief and still includes purpose.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You are not only someone who lost.

You are someone who loved and still has life ahead. Your words should reflect the full truth.

cards.title: Choose What You Want Your Identity to Include
cards.prompt: What part of yourself do you want to reclaim?
options: My ability to love and connect.

cards.title: Write Your Identity Statement
bullets: Write 3 lines:
“I am a person who…”
“I am allowed to…”
“In this season, I am becoming…”
Read it out loud.
Save it and read it each morning for 7 days. Notice what it changes in your mindset.

cards.title: Keep This in Mind
cards.text:
Your identity statement won’t erase grief.

It will stop grief from erasing you.

missions.title: Step into Your Next Season
missions.subtitle: Your Next Season Begins with One Brave Step.
missions.whyThisMatters:
A new season doesn’t start when you feel ready.

It starts when you decide to move with God one step at a time. Today you will choose a meaningful step that aligns with your new identity.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Your future is not a betrayal.

It is a season God can still fill with purpose and love.

cards.title: Choose Your Next Season Step
cards.prompt: Which step would signal a new season for you?
options: Serving in church or helping others.

cards.title: Choose and Schedule the Step
bullets: Pick one step and make it specific.
Write when you will do it in the next 7 days.
Tell one safe person so you don’t do it alone.
After you do it, journal: “What did I learn about myself?”
Close with: “God is with me in my next season.”

cards.title: A Calm Note
cards.text:
A season doesn’t change overnight.

It changes through repeated steps. The brave thing is to start.

completionCard.title: Journey complete
completionCard.message: You rebuilt stability and purpose step by step.

journeys.title: Honoring the Past While Moving Forward
journeys.summary: Activities to honor your spouse’s memory while giving yourself peractivity to keep living.

milestones.title: Halfway through
milestones.message: You are honoring love and choosing life at the same time.

missions.title: Stop Suffering in Silence
missions.subtitle: Isolation Makes Grief Heavier.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Loneliness after loss can feel like an invisible weight. Many widows and widowers isolate because it feels safer, but isolation increases pain over time.

In this step you’ll take one small step out of silence.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You don’t have to explain everything.

You only need one safe moment of connection today.

cards.title: Choose What Keeps You Silent
cards.prompt: What usually makes you stay quiet?
options: I don’t want to burden anyone.
I feel like people won’t understand.
I’m tired of talking about it.
I feel embarrassed to be lonely.

cards.title: Send the One Message
bullets: Choose one safe person.
Send one sentence: “I’ve been feeling lonely. Can we talk this week?”
If that feels hard, use: “Can we take a walk sometime this week?”
Put a date and time suggestion in the message.
Finish with: “I’m allowed to need people.”

cards.title: A Steady Reminder
cards.text:
Loneliness doesn’t mean you’re failing.

It means you’re human. Connection is part of healing, not a reward for being strong.

Here’s what it can look like: when you feel guilty for joy, whisper, “Love and life can exist together.” Then take the next step anyway.

A woman said, “After the funeral, everyone went back to their lives. I stayed in the house for days because I didn’t know what to do with the quiet.

Take one step. Don’t rush.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text:
Father, help me reach out instead of hiding. Place safe people around me and give me courage to receive support.

Amen.

missions.title: Create One Safe Connection
missions.subtitle: One Safe Connection Can Change Your Week.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Loneliness feels unbearable when you believe no one understands you.

But healing does not require many people. It requires the right person. Today you will identify one safe connection and move toward them without over-explaining yourself.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
The goal is not to become social overnight.

The goal is one safe connection that reduces isolation.

cards.title: Choose Who Feels Safest
cards.prompt: Who is most likely to be a safe connection right now?
options: A close friend who listens well.
A family member who checks on me.
A support group or community member.
Someone who has also experienced loss.

cards.title: Make the Connection Plan
bullets: Write the person’s name.
Write the simplest request: “Can we talk this week?” or “Can we sit together after church?”
Choose a day and time to reach out.
If fear rises, remind yourself: “Connection is healing.”
After the conversation, write one line: “I was not alone.”

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Not everyone is safe.

Choose someone who listens, respects your pace. And doesn’t rush your grief.

completionCard.title: You created honor
completionCard.message: A ritual gave memory a safe place.

missions.title: Build a Weekly Rhythm
missions.subtitle: Loneliness Grows When Your Week Has No Anchors.
missions.whyThisMatters:
After loss, days can blur into each other.

You may stay inside, scroll, and feel stuck. Today you will create a weekly rhythm with small anchors that bring structure and connection.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
A rhythm is not a busy schedule.

It is a few planned moments that keep you grounded.

cards.title: Choose What Your Week Needs Most
cards.prompt: Which anchor would help you most this week?
options: One memory honor moment (gratitude, prayer, journaling).

cards.title: Create Your 5-anchor Week
bullets: Pick 3 anchors from the options above.
Write the day and time for each anchor.
Keep each anchor short (30-90 minutes).
Place it on your calendar.
At the end of the week, reflect: “Which anchor helped me most?”

cards.title: Keep This in Mind
cards.text:
Loneliness feels bigger when time is empty.

Anchors give your heart something to hold onto.

missions.title: Handle Evenings Better
missions.subtitle: Evenings Can Be the Hardest Part of the Day.
missions.whyThisMatters: Many widowed people say the day is manageable until evening arrives and the quiet hits. Today you will build a predictable evening plan so you’re not emotionally ambushed when the sun goes down.

cards.title: Take a Deep Breath
cards.text:
Evenings don’t need to be perfect.

They need structure and comfort.

cards.title: Choose What Evenings Usually Trigger
cards.prompt: What is most painful about evenings for you?

cards.title: Create Your Evening Plan
bullets: Choose one comfort action: shower, tea, worship music, reading, journaling.
Choose one light activity: tidy one space, prep tomorrow, short walk.
Choose one connection: text a friend or join a group chat.
Set a phone cutoff time.
Close with one sentence: “This is a hard hour, not a hard life.”

cards.title: A Small Story
cards.text: A widower shared, “Evenings felt like a door closing.” He built a simple plan: tea, a short walk, and one phone call twice a week. It didn’t erase grief, but it stopped the night from swallowing him.

completionCard.title: You honored love
completionCard.message: That story kept love alive in a healthy way.

missions.title: Leave the House Gently
missions.subtitle: Your World Shouldn’t Shrink to Your Living Room.
missions.whyThisMatters:
After loss, leaving the house can feel exhausting.

But staying inside too long can deepen loneliness and fear. Today you will re-enter life gently through one small outing.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text: You don’t need a big outing. You need one step outside that reminds your mind: life still exists.

cards.title: Choose a Gentle Outing
cards.prompt: Which outing feels realistic this week?
options: A short walk around my area.
A quick grocery trip at a calm time.
Sitting in a café for 20 minutes.

cards.title: Plan the Outing
bullets: Pick one outing and set the day and time.
Decide your time limit (20-60 minutes).
Choose one calming tool (music, prayer line, deep breathing).
Go, then come home and journal one line: “I showed up.”
Repeat a gentle outing once a week for a month.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Courage after loss is not dramatic.

It is showing up in small ways, again and again.

completionCard.title: You chose life
completionCard.message: That step was healthy and brave.

missions.title: Stop Comparing Your Life
missions.subtitle: Comparison Turns Grief into Shame.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Seeing couples, families, and happy moments can trigger anger, sadness, and bitterness.

Comparison whispers, “My life is broken.” Today you will interrupt comparison and return to your own healing journey.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Comparison doesn’t tell the truth.

It only shows you what you’re missing in that moment.

cards.title: Choose Your Comparison Trigger
cards.prompt: What triggers comparison most for you?

cards.title: Do the Comparison Reset
bullets: When comparison hits, say: “This is pain talking.”
Put your hand on your chest and breathe out slowly for 6.
Write one truth: “My story is not finished.”
Choose one action: log off, step away, or message someone safe.
At the end of the day, write one gratitude line about your own life.

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text:
Comparison will always find something to steal your peace.

Healing is learning to return to your own path quickly.

missions.title: Ask for Companionship Clearly
missions.subtitle: People Can’t Meet Needs They Don’t Know.
missions.whyThisMatters: Many widowed people say, “I’m lonely,” but they don’t ask for companionship because they fear burdening others. Today you will make a clear companionship request without shame.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Companionship is not a luxury.

It is a human need, especially in grief.

cards.title: Choose What Companionship Looks Like
cards.prompt: What kind of companionship do you need most?
options: Someone to eat with once a week.
Someone to sit with me when I feel heavy.

cards.title: Make the Companionship Request
bullets: Choose one person who feels safe.
Send: “Can you do ______ with me this week?”
Offer two options for timing.
If they agree, put it on the calendar immediately.
If they can’t, ask a second person rather than retreating.

cards.title: A Calm Note
cards.text:
Strong people still need company.

Asking is not weakness. Asking is wisdom.

missions.title: Build a Support Circle
missions.subtitle: Healing Accelerates When Support Is Organized.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Support feels confusing when it is random.

Some days you get many calls, then silence. Today you will build a support circle with roles so you’re held consistently.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You don’t need many helpers.

You need a small circle with clarity.

cards.title: Choose Your Support Roles
cards.prompt: Which roles do you need in your circle?
options: Emergency support (someone I can call when overwhelmed).

cards.title: Build Your Circle
bullets: Write 3-5 names and assign them one role each.
Send a simple message: “Can you be my ______ support for the next month?”
Set one weekly check-in with at least one person.
Save your circle list on your phone.
When you feel overwhelmed, use the list instead of isolating.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Clarity reduces disappointment.

People feel honored when they know how to support you.

completionCard.title: You allowed real grief
completionCard.message: You didn’t force yourself to be okay.

missions.title: Practice Joy Without Guilt
missions.subtitle:
Joy Is Not Betrayal.

Joy Is Part of Healing.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Many widowed people feel guilty when they laugh, enjoy something, or feel calm.

But joy is not disloyalty. Today you will practice joy gently and release guilt.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Joy does not erase love.

Joy is proof that you are still alive.

cards.title: Choose What Triggers Guilt
cards.prompt: When you feel a moment of joy, what thought shows up?
options: It means I didn’t love them enough.
It feels unsafe to be joyful.

cards.title: The Joy Permission Exercise
bullets: Write: “Joy does not erase love.”
Choose one gentle joy activity (music, meal, walk, comedy clip, time with a friend).
Do it for 10 minutes, without apology.
Afterward, write: “What did I feel? What did guilt say?”
Respond with truth: “My joy honors the life I still have.”

cards.title: A Small Story
cards.text: A widow said, “The first time I laughed with someone, guilt hit me immediately.” She learned to whisper, “This joy does not erase my love.” That sentence helped her breathe again.

missions.title: Stay Connected for the Long Run
missions.subtitle: Support Must Last Beyond the Early Weeks.
missions.whyThisMatters:
After loss, support often fades after the funeral.

But grief continues. Today you will plan long-term connection so you’re not abandoned emotionally months later.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Grief is not a short season.

Your support should not be short either.

cards.title: Choose Your Long-term Need
cards.prompt: What would help you most over the next 3 months?
options: A grief support group or church group.
Someone to help with practical tasks monthly.

cards.title: Create a 3-month Plan
bullets: Choose one long-term need from the list.
Pick 2 people who can support that need.
Send: “Can we do this once a week/month for the next 3 months?”
Put the dates on your calendar now.
After 3 months, reassess what you need next.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Consistency heals.

Random support comforts you for a day. Consistent support strengthens you for months.

completionCard.title: Journey complete
completionCard.message: You honored the past and moved forward with grace.

journeys.title: Rediscovering Identity and Purpose
journeys.summary: Activities to rediscover who you are now, rebuild confidence, and find purpose again.

milestones.title: Halfway through
milestones.message: You are becoming stronger and steadier.

missions.title: Face the Numbers Calmly
missions.subtitle: Avoidance Increases Anxiety.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Many widows and widowers avoid finances because it feels overwhelming or because the spouse handled it.

But avoidance creates more fear. This time you will face your numbers calmly, one step at a time.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You’re not trying to solve everything today.

You’re trying to see clearly. Clarity reduces panic.

cards.title: Choose Your Biggest Fear
cards.prompt: What part of finances scares you most right now?
options: Feeling ashamed that I don’t understand things.

cards.title: Your 20-minute Money Check
bullets: Set a timer for 20 minutes.
List your monthly income sources.
List your 5 most important bills.
Answer  your current account balances (even if it’s uncomfortable).
Journal  one next step: call the bank, ask a trusted person, or schedule a meeting.
Finish with: “Facts give me power. Fear does not.”

cards.title: A Real Reminder
cards.text:
Many people panic because they don’t know. The moment you see your numbers, the fear reduces because you’re no longer guessing. in real life: when your chest tightens after a memory, pause, breathe out slowly, and do one grounding act.

This is how you stay steady.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text:
Father, give me wisdom and peace.

Help me face my responsibilities with calm and clarity. Provide what I need.

Amen.

missions.title: Separate Fear from Facts
missions.subtitle: Clarity Reduces Panic.
missions.whyThisMatters:
After loss, finances can feel terrifying because they represent survival.

Fear makes everything feel bigger than it is. Today you will separate fear from facts so you can make decisions calmly.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Fear says: I can’t handle this.

Facts say: I can take one step. Today you will work with facts.

cards.title: Choose Your Fear Sentence
cards.prompt: Which fear sentence hits you hardest?
options: I’m scared I won’t have enough.
I’m scared I’ll make a mistake.
I’m scared I don’t understand anything.
I’m scared of what I’ll find out.
I’m scared of dealing with institutions alone.

cards.title: Do the Fear Vs Facts Split
bullets: Write your fear sentence at the top of a page.
Draw a line down the middle: FEAR on the left, FACTS on the right.
Under FEAR, list what your mind is imagining.
Under FACTS, list what you know for sure (income, bills, savings, support).
Circle one fact-based next step you can do this week.
Finish with: “I will not let fear lead.”

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Fear grows in the dark.

Facts turn on the light. You do not need bravery.

You need clarity.

missions.title: Create a Small Budget
missions.subtitle: A Simple Budget Is a Safety Plan, Not a Punishment.
missions.whyThisMatters: Budgeting can feel shameful or overwhelming, especially if your spouse handled finances. Today you will build a simple budget that protects you and reduces anxiety.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text: Your budget is not about restriction. It is about knowing where your money is going so you feel safe.

cards.title: Choose Your Biggest Budget Struggle
cards.prompt: What makes budgeting hardest for you?
options: I avoid looking because it stresses me out.
I spend impulsively when I feel sad.
I feel ashamed that I’m behind.
I don’t know how to start.

cards.title: Build the 3-category Budget
bullets: Write your total monthly income.
Create 3 categories:
Needs: rent, food, bills, transport.
Obligations: debts, school fees, family support.
Care: savings, emergency buffer, self-care.
Assign a rough amount to each category. Keep it simple. Pick one area to reduce slightly this month and one area to protect.

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text:
Most budgets fail because they are too complex.

Simple budgets work because you can actually follow them.

missions.title: Handle Bills Without Panic
missions.subtitle: Bills Feel Heavier When You Avoid Them.
missions.whyThisMatters: Bills can become emotionally loaded because they remind you of what changed. Today you will handle bills with a calm system so you don’t panic loop every time a payment is due.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Bills are not personal.

They are responsibilities. You can handle them one by one.

cards.title: Choose What Triggers Panic
cards.prompt: What makes bills stressful for you?
options: I’m afraid of missing due dates.
I’m afraid I can’t afford everything.
I feel angry that I’m doing this alone.
I don’t know what accounts exist.

cards.title: Set up the Bill System
bullets: List your top 8 bills and their due dates.
Choose a bill day (example: every Saturday morning).
Set phone reminders for each due date.
If possible, set up automatic payments for at least two bills.
Place all bill documents in one folder or one drawer.
After you complete this, write: “I am building stability.”

cards.title: A Small Example
cards.text:
A widow said, “I avoided opening letters for weeks.” She chose one “bill day” each week and opened everything with a friend on speakerphone.

Fear reduced because she stopped facing it alone.

missions.title: Build a Safety Buffer
missions.subtitle: A Buffer Reduces Fear.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Even a small emergency fund can calm your nervous system.

It tells your heart: we have a cushion. Today you will start a safety buffer, even if it’s small.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
A buffer is not about wealth.

It is about peace. Small amounts still matter.

cards.title: Choose Your Buffer Reality
cards.prompt: Which feels most true about saving right now?
options: I can save a little each week.
I want to save but I feel overwhelmed.
I’m scared to save because I’m barely surviving.
I have savings but I’m afraid to touch it.
I don’t know what amount is realistic.

cards.title: Start the Buffer
bullets: Choose a realistic buffer goal for the next 30 days (even 10,000 Naira).
Set an automatic transfer or plan a weekly deposit.
Label the savings account: “Peace Buffer.”
Track each deposit with a simple note.
When you save, say: “I am protecting my future.”

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Savings reduces anxiety because it creates options.

Options reduce fear.

missions.title: Ask for Help with Practical Tasks
missions.subtitle: Competence Grows Faster with Support.
missions.whyThisMatters: If your spouse handled certain tasks, you may feel lost. Today you will ask for practical help without shame so you learn and become confident.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Asking for help is not weakness.

It is mentorship. Today you will request support for one practical task.

cards.title: Choose the Task You Need Help with
cards.prompt: Which practical task do you need support with?

cards.title: Make the Practical Help Request
bullets: Choose one trusted person who is competent.
Message them: “Can you help me understand ______ this week?”
Prepare 3 questions you want answered.
During the help session, take notes.
After, write: “I am learning. I am becoming capable.”

cards.title: A Calm Note
cards.text:
Most people feel honored to help when the request is clear.

Competence is built through learning, not shame.

completionCard.title: You refreshed your space
completionCard.message: Your space supported your new chapter.

missions.title: Make One Phone Call
missions.subtitle: One Call Can Unblock a Whole Month of Stress.
missions.whyThisMatters: Institutions can feel intimidating, and you may avoid calls because you fear bad news or embarrassment. Today you will make one important call with confidence and preparation.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You don’t need to make ten calls.

You need one. Small courage creates momentum.

cards.title: Choose the Call You’ve Been Avoiding
cards.prompt: Which call would reduce stress the most?

cards.title: Prepare and Make the Call
bullets: Write the purpose of your call in one sentence.
Write 3 questions you need answered.
Keep a pen and paper beside you.
Make the call and write down the outcome immediately.
After the call, do one calming action (water, breathing, short walk). Tell yourself: “I can do hard things.”

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text: Avoidance keeps your stress high. Action lowers stress because it gives you information and control.

missions.title: Plan for the Next 90 Days
missions.subtitle: Short-term Planning Reduces Overwhelm.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Long-term planning can feel impossible after loss.

But 90 days is manageable. Today you will map your next three months so you feel steadier.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You’re not planning a whole life.

You’re planning a season. That’s enough.

cards.title: Choose Your 90-day Focus
cards.prompt: Which focus would help you feel most stable in the next 90 days?

cards.title: Create the 90-day Map
bullets: Write your focus at the top of a page.
Divide the page into 3 months.
For each month, write one key action (example: Month 1 organize paperwork, Month 2 set budget, Month 3 build buffer).
Choose one action to begin this week.
Schedule it.
Review the plan every Sunday for 5 minutes.

cards.title: Keep This in Mind
cards.text:
Stability is built through planning and follow-through.

Small plans create big peace over time.

missions.title: Stop Avoiding Important Papers
missions.subtitle: Paperwork Often Holds Emotional Weight.
missions.whyThisMatters: Documents can trigger grief because they force you to face reality: certificates, accounts, legal papers. Today you will organize papers in a way that feels manageable and emotionally safe.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Paperwork is not only practical.

It is emotional. Approach it gently, but do not avoid it.

cards.title: Choose What You Avoid Most
cards.prompt: What type of document is hardest to face?

cards.title: Do the 3-folder Method
bullets: Create 3 folders: URGENT, IMPORTANT, LATER.
Set a timer for 25 minutes.
Sort papers quickly without reading everything.
Move any grief-heavy papers into IMPORTANT, not URGENT, unless needed immediately.
After sorting, take a break and do something calming. Plan one more 25-minute session later this week.

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text:
Organizing documents is not cold.

It is responsible. It protects you and honors the life you are stewarding.

missions.title: Choose Financial Peace
missions.subtitle: Peace Comes from Systems, Not Wishful Thinking.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Financial peace is not about having a lot.

It is about clarity, systems, and consistent follow-through. Today you will choose one financial system that brings you peace over the next month.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Peace is possible, even with limited money.

The secret is a system you can maintain.

cards.title: Choose Your Peace System
cards.prompt: Which system would bring you the most peace right now?

cards.title: Commit to the System
bullets: Pick one system and write it clearly.
Choose a start date within 7 days.
Set a reminder on your phone.
Tell one trusted person so you stay accountable.
After two weeks, review what is working and adjust gently.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Financial peace is not a one-time achievement.

It is repeated small choices that reduce stress over time.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text:
Father, give me wisdom and peace with my finances.

Help me build systems that protect my life and future. Amen.

completionCard.title: Journey complete
completionCard.message: You rebuilt identity and purpose with steady steps.

journeys.title: Emotional Readiness for Love Again
journeys.summary: Activities to know when you are ready, reduce guilt, and approach love again with calm wisdom.

milestones.title: Halfway through
milestones.message: You are preparing your heart with wisdom and gentleness.

missions.title: Tell God the Truth
missions.subtitle: God Can Handle Your Honesty.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Loss can shake faith deeply.

Some people feel angry, confused, or numb. Others feel guilty for not being joyful. In this session you will speak honestly to God without pretending, because honesty is where healing starts.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
God is not fragile.

You don’t need to perform faith. You can tell Him the truth with respect and honesty.

cards.title: Choose What You’ve Been Holding Back
cards.prompt: Which truth have you been afraid to say to God?

cards.title: Pray the Honest Prayer
bullets: Start with: “God, this is what I really feel…”
Answer  one paragraph without editing yourself.
Then write: “What I need from You is…”
Read Psalm 34: 18 or Psalm 23 slowly.
Finish with: “Even in my pain, I’m still here with You.”

cards.title: A Quick Truth
cards.text:
Silence from God is not rejection.

Sometimes grief makes it hard to feel Him. But He remains near, especially to the brokenhearted. example: when the quiet feels loud, choose one small action instead of scrolling for hours.

That is how you protect your heart.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text:
Father, I bring You my real heart.

Meet me in my pain. Help me trust You even when I don’t understand.

Amen.

missions.title: Stop Pretending You’re Fine
missions.subtitle: God Meets the Real You, Not the Edited You.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Many Christians try to be strong in grief, especially in church spaces.

But pretending blocks healing. Today you will bring your real emotions to God without fear, guilt, or performance.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You don’t have to perform faith.

You can bring tears, questions, and anger to God. He can handle your truth.

cards.title: Choose How You Hide
cards.prompt: How do you usually pretend you’re fine?
options: I say “I’m okay” even when I’m not.
I quote scripture to avoid feelings.
I keep busy so I don’t break down.
I withdraw because I don’t want questions.
I smile so people stop worrying.

cards.title: Pray the Unedited Prayer
bullets: Start with: “God, here is what I am really feeling…”
Write one honest paragraph without fixing your tone.
Add: “What I need from You today is…”
Read Psalm 13 slowly and underline one line that sounds like you.
Finish by saying: “I am still here with You.”

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text: Faith is not pretending you’re okay. Faith is bringing your real heart to God and staying in the relationship.

missions.title: Read One Psalm Slowly
missions.subtitle: Scripture Becomes Medicine When You Slow Down.
missions.whyThisMatters:
In grief, the Bible can feel hard to read.

Your mind wanders, and your heart feels numb. Today you will read one Psalm slowly in a way that connects to your real life.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You are not reading to impress God.

You are reading to be held by truth.

cards.title: Choose Your Psalm for Today
cards.prompt: Which Psalm fits your heart most right now?
options: Psalm 42 (Why are you downcast, O my soul).

cards.title: The Slow Psalm Practice
bullets: Read the Psalm out loud, slowly.
Underline one line that hits you.
Write: “This line matters because…”
Turn it into a prayer: “God, please be this for me…”
Sit in silence for 2 minutes and breathe.
Repeat the same Psalm tomorrow, not a new one.

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text: In grief, repetition is powerful. The same Psalm repeated becomes a steady voice when your mind feels unstable.

missions.title: Pray When You Feel Numb
missions.subtitle: You Can Be Numb and Still Be Loved by God.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Numbness is common in grief.

It can make you feel guilty or spiritually broken. Today you will pray even when you feel nothing, using simple words and steady practice.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Numbness is not rebellion.

It is protection. God is not offended by your quiet.

cards.title: Choose Your Numbness Experience
cards.prompt: What does numbness feel like for you?
options: I feel like my prayers bounce off the ceiling.
I feel guilty because I don’t feel God.
I feel like I’m watching my life from outside.

cards.title: The 3-line Prayer
bullets: Say out loud:
“God, I’m here.”
“I don’t have words.”
“Hold me anyway.”
Then read one verse (Psalm 34: 18 or Isaiah 41:10).
Do this for 3 days, even if you feel nothing.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Feelings come and go.

God stays. Consistent prayer is a bridge back to connection.

missions.title: Release Anger Toward God
missions.subtitle: Anger Is Often Grief with Nowhere to Go.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Some widowed people feel angry at God: why did He allow this, why didn’t He stop it, why did prayer not change it.

Many hide that anger out of fear. Today you will process anger respectfully and honestly.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
God is not threatened by your anger.

He is a Father. You can bring Him your real heart.

cards.title: Choose What Your Anger Sounds Like
cards.prompt: Which statement feels closest to your anger?
options: I don’t understand why God allowed this.
I feel betrayed by unanswered prayers.
I’m angry that life is unfair.
I’m angry that other people still have what I lost.

cards.title: Write the Anger Letter
bullets: Write a letter to God starting with: “Lord, I am angry because…”
Do not edit your emotion, but keep it respectful.
Then write: “Under my anger, I am really afraid of…”
End with: “God, please meet me in this.”
Read Psalm 13 or Job 3 for honesty.
If you feel relief, thank God for holding you.

cards.title: Keep This in Mind
cards.text:
Anger becomes harmful when it isolates you from God.

Honesty keeps you connected, even when your heart is hurting.

missions.title: Return to Church Gently
missions.subtitle: Church Can Heal, but It Can Also Feel Painful.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Some people avoid church because it reminds them of their spouse or because they fear judgment and awkward questions.

But isolation is not the answer. Today you will re-enter church gently and safely.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You don’t have to be strong at church.

You can attend quietly. You can cry.

You can sit in the back. God still meets you.

cards.title: Choose Your Church Barrier
cards.prompt: What makes church hardest right now?
options: The seat we used to sit in.
Feeling angry at God in worship.

cards.title: Plan Your Gentle Return
bullets: Choose one service or gathering to attend this month.
Decide where you will sit and who you will sit with.
Prepare one sentence for questions: “I’m taking it one day at a time.”
Give yourself permission to leave early if needed.
After church, journal: “What helped? What hurt? What I need next time is…”

cards.title: A Calm Note
cards.text:
Church is not a stage for perfection.

It is a home for the broken. Your grief belongs there too.

missions.title: Let People Pray with You
missions.subtitle: Letting Others Carry You Is Part of Healing.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Many widowed people pray alone because they don’t want to cry in front of others.

But being prayed for can become a powerful comfort. Today you will receive prayer without shame.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Receiving prayer is not attention-seeking.

It is allowing the Body of Christ to support you.

cards.title: Choose What Stops You
cards.prompt: What makes it hard to let people pray with you?
options: I don’t want to be a burden.
I’m afraid people will say the wrong thing.
I feel numb and don’t want spiritual pressure.

cards.title: Receive Prayer Safely
bullets: Choose one trusted person.
Send: “Can you pray with me this week? I don’t need advice.”
When they pray, focus on breathing slowly.
After prayer, say: “Thank you for holding this with me.”
Later, write one sentence: “I was supported.”

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
You don’t have to be strong alone.

God often comforts us through people.

missions.title: Trust God with Tomorrow
missions.subtitle: Your Future Can Feel Scary After Loss.
missions.whyThisMatters: After losing someone, tomorrow can feel uncertain and unsafe. Today you will surrender tomorrow to God without denying your fear.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Trust is not the absence of fear.

Trust is choosing God even with fear.

cards.title: Choose Your Future Fear
cards.prompt: What future fear worries you most?
options: Feeling like life will never be meaningful.

cards.title: The Tomorrow Surrender
bullets: Write your biggest future fear.
Write: “God, I give You this fear.”
Write one promise: Isaiah 41:10 or Matthew 6:34.
Choose one practical step you can take this week that matches wisdom (budget, connection, rest).
Finish with: “I will handle today. God will hold tomorrow.”

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text:
God rarely gives you the whole plan at once.

He gives you daily bread, one day at a time.

completionCard.title: You practiced steadiness
completionCard.message: Your story sounded calm and healthy.

missions.title: Listen for Comfort
missions.subtitle: Comfort Often Comes Quietly.
missions.whyThisMatters:
In grief, you may expect comfort to feel dramatic. But God often comforts through small moments: a verse, a friend’s message, a song, a peaceful breath.

Today you will notice comfort instead of missing it.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Comfort is not always loud.

Sometimes it is a small moment that keeps you from collapsing.

cards.title: Choose Where Comfort Comes to You
cards.prompt: Where do you most often sense comfort?

cards.title: Do the Comfort Journal
bullets: For the next 24 hours, watch for one comfort moment.
When you notice it, write: “God, thank You for this.”
Describe what happened in 2 sentences.
At night, read the entry and breathe slowly.
Repeat for 5 days. You are training your heart to notice grace.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Comfort doesn’t remove grief.

But it keeps grief from becoming hopeless.

missions.title: Choose Faith in Small Steps
missions.subtitle: Small Faith Steps Rebuild Spiritual Strength.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Some days you will not feel like praying, reading, or worshiping.

But small consistent steps rebuild spiritual strength. Today you will choose a faith practice you can actually maintain.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text: Strong faith is built through small repeated steps, not big emotional moments.

cards.title: Choose Your Faith Practice
cards.prompt: Which practice feels most realistic for you this week?
options: One phone call with a prayer partner.

cards.title: Commit to the Practice
bullets: Choose one practice and set a reminder.
Write the plan in one sentence: “This week I will…”
Do it for 5 days, even if you feel nothing.
After 5 days, journal: “What changed in my mind and heart?”
Keep what works and simplify what doesn’t.

cards.title: Keep This in Mind
cards.text:
Faith is not measured by emotion.

Faith is measured by return. Keep returning.

completionCard.title: Journey complete
completionCard.message: You prepared your heart with wisdom and gentleness.

journeys.title: Opening the Heart to New Love
journeys.summary: Activities to open your heart gently, reduce fear, and take healthy steps toward love again.

milestones.title: Halfway through
milestones.message: You are becoming stronger and steadier.

missions.title: Anchor Your Child Today
missions.subtitle: Your Child Needs Stability, Not Perfection.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Children feel loss differently at different ages.

What stays constant is their need for safety. Here you’ll build one anchor that helps your child feel steady, even while you’re grieving.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Your child’s nervous system borrows safety from you.

You don’t need to be cheerful. You need to be steady.

cards.title: Choose What Your Child Needs Most
cards.prompt: What does your child need from you right now?

cards.title: Create One Anchor
bullets: Pick one daily anchor: bedtime prayer, dinner together, school pickup routine, or a nightly check-in.
Tell your child: “Even though we miss them, we will be okay.”
Ask one gentle question: “What was the hardest part of today?”
Finish with: “You are safe with me.”

cards.title: A Real Reminder
cards.text:
Children don’t need you to hide grief. They need you to show them grief can be carried with love and stability.

Here’s what it can look like: when your chest tightens after a memory, pause, breathe out slowly, and do one grounding act.

This is how you stay steady.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text:
Father, help me parent with wisdom and gentleness.

Give my child comfort and security in this season. Amen.

missions.title: Explain the Loss Clearly
missions.subtitle: Clarity Reduces Fear for Children.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Children often fill gaps with scary ideas.

If the explanation is vague, they imagine the worst. Today you will explain the loss in a gentle, age-appropriate way that gives safety and room for questions.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You don’t need perfect words.

You need clear words. Children feel safer when they know what happened in a simple way.

cards.title: Choose Your Child’s Age Group
cards.prompt: Which age group best fits your child?

cards.title: Use the 4-sentence Explanation
bullets: Sentence 1: What happened (simple): “Daddy/Mummy died.”
Sentence 2: What it means: “Their body stopped working and they cannot come back.”
Sentence 3: Safety: “You are safe and I am here.”
Sentence 4: Invitation: “You can ask me anything anytime.”
After you explain, ask: “What did you hear me say?” to check understanding.

cards.title: A Small Story
cards.text:
One child asked, “Are you going to die too?” The parent didn’t dismiss it.

They said, “I’m here, and we are safe.” That honest reassurance became the child’s anchor.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text:
Lord, give me wisdom to speak clearly and gently to my child.

Help my words bring safety. Amen.

missions.title: Respond to Their Fear Questions
missions.subtitle: Kids Ask the Same Questions Because They Are Processing.
missions.whyThisMatters: Children repeat questions like “Where are they now?” or “Why did God allow it?” not to frustrate you, but to feel safe. Today you will answer without overloading them and without shutting them down.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text: Repeated questions are normal. Your calm answers teach your child: hard things can be spoken about safely.

cards.title: Choose the Question You Hear Most
cards.prompt: Which question comes up most often?
options: Will it happen to me too?
Are you going to leave me too?

cards.title: Use the Calm Answer Method
bullets: C - Calm your tone and body first (breathe once).
A - Answer simply (one or two sentences).
L - Label the emotion: “That question sounds scary.”
M - Make safety clear: “You are safe and I am here.”
Then ask: “Do you want a hug or do you want to talk more?”

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Children don’t need a full theological answer.

They need safety, honesty. And permission to ask again.

missions.title: Handle Anger and Tantrums
missions.subtitle: Anger Is Often Grief with No Language.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Some children act out after loss.

They may hit, shout, disobey, or become disrespectful. Today you will respond firmly and gently so you don’t punish grief, but you still maintain boundaries.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Your child is not becoming “bad.” They are overwhelmed.

Your job is to create safety and boundaries at the same time.

cards.title: Choose the Behavior You’re Seeing
cards.prompt: Which behavior is most common right now?

cards.title: Use the Firm and Gentle Response
bullets: Step 1: Get low and calm: “I see you’re angry.”
Step 2: Boundary: “We don’t hit. We can cry.”
Step 3: Offer a safe outlet: “You can stomp your feet or squeeze a pillow.”
Step 4: After the storm, reconnect: “I’m here. I love you.”
Step 5: Later, ask: “What were you feeling inside?”

cards.title: Keep This in Mind
cards.text:
Children repeat behaviors when they feel unsafe.

Consistent calm boundaries slowly teach regulation.

missions.title: Rebuild Predictable Routines
missions.subtitle: Routines Tell Children the World Is Still Stable.
missions.whyThisMatters:
After loss, children may fear more loss.

Routines reduce that fear. Today you will rebuild predictable rhythms so your child knows what to expect.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text: Predictability is one of the greatest gifts you can give a grieving child.

cards.title: Choose Where Routines Are Breaking
cards.prompt: Which routine is most unstable right now?

cards.title: Create the Routine Reset
bullets: Choose one routine to stabilize first.
Write a simple 3-step routine (example: bath, story, prayer).
Post it somewhere visible.
Practice it for 7 days with consistency.
Praise effort, not perfection.
At the end of 7 days, adjust gently if needed.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Children don’t need a perfect home.

They need a predictable one. Routine reduces anxiety.

missions.title: Help Them Talk About Feelings
missions.subtitle: Talking Prevents Grief from Turning into Fear or Shame.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Some children don’t have words for grief.

They may hold everything inside, then explode later. Today you will create a simple emotional language practice that fits your family.

cards.title: Start Here
