cards.text:
Feelings are not dangerous.

Silence makes them dangerous. Today you’ll build a safe way for feelings to be expressed.

cards.title: Choose How Your Child Expresses Grief
cards.prompt: How does your child express grief most often?

cards.title: Start the Daily 5-minute Check-in
bullets: Pick a consistent time (bedtime or dinner).
Ask: “What was the hardest part of today?”
Ask: “What was one good moment today?”
Name their feeling: “That sounds sad/angry/scary.”
Close with reassurance: “You are safe with me.”
Do this daily for 7 days.

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text:
Children may not answer immediately.

The power is the consistent invitation.

missions.title: Manage Your Own Breakdown
missions.subtitle: Your Child Needs You Steady, Not Emotionless.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Parenting while grieving is heavy.

You may break down, feel overwhelmed, or snap. Today you will create a plan for your own emotional moments so you can recover quickly and still parent well.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You are carrying a lot.

Your child does not need you to be perfect. They need you to recover and return.

cards.title: Choose Your Hardest Moment
cards.prompt: When do you break down most often?
options: At night when everyone is asleep
When I’m alone in the house
When I see reminders of my spouse

cards.title: Create Your Breakdown Plan
bullets: Choose one safe adult you can call or text.
Write one sentence you will say to your child when you are overwhelmed: “I’m feeling heavy, but I’m okay.”
Pick one reset tool: water, breathing, short walk, prayer, shower.
When you snap, restore quickly: “I’m sorry. I was overwhelmed. I love you.”
Schedule one support moment this week just for you.

cards.title: A Small Story
cards.text:
A teen once said, “Stop acting like you’re fine.” That moment reminded the parent that children don’t need perfection.

They need honesty and stability.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text:
Lord, strengthen me as I parent in grief.

Help me recover when I fall apart and return with love. Amen.

missions.title: Support Them at School
missions.subtitle: School Is a Major Stress Point After Loss.
missions.whyThisMatters: Teachers may not understand how grief affects your child. Your child may struggle with concentration, behavior, or friendships. Today you will communicate with the school and advocate for your child.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text: Advocacy is love. Your child should not have to carry grief alone in school spaces.

cards.title: Choose the School Challenge
cards.prompt: What is the school problem right now?

cards.title: Do the School Support Plan
bullets: Send one message to your child’s teacher explaining the loss briefly.
Ask for 2 accommodations (extra patience, check-ins, flexibility).
Ask the teacher to notify you of major behavior changes.
Talk to your child: “If you feel overwhelmed, who can you go to?”
Follow up once a month for 3 months.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Children’s grief often shows up as behavior, not words.

School support can prevent shame.

missions.title: Handle Milestones and Holidays
missions.subtitle: Milestones Can Trigger Grief for the Whole Family.
missions.whyThisMatters: Birthdays, holidays, anniversaries, and school events can bring fresh pain. Today you will plan for milestones so your child feels supported and you don’t get blindsided.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Milestones don’t have to be perfect.

They need a plan. A plan reduces anxiety for you and your child.

cards.title: Choose Your Next Milestone
cards.prompt: Which milestone is coming up soon?

cards.title: Create the Milestone Plan
bullets: Ask your child: “Do you want to acknowledge them or keep it simple?”
Choose one honor act (prayer, candle, photo, memory sharing).
Choose one comfort act (favorite meal, outing, gift, rest).
Decide what you will say if emotions rise: “It’s okay to miss them.”
After the milestone, debrief: “What helped? What hurt?”

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text:
Planning doesn’t remove sadness.

It prevents chaos. That stability is what children remember.

missions.title: Help Your Child Hope Again
missions.subtitle: Hope Helps Children Feel Safe in the Future.
missions.whyThisMatters: Children may fear that life will always be painful or that another loss will happen. Today you will teach hope without pretending everything is fine.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text: Hope is not ignoring grief. Hope is believing life can still hold good moments and God can still carry you.

cards.title: Choose Your Child’s Fear
cards.prompt: Which fear seems strongest in your child?
options: Fear of talking about the lost parent

cards.title: Teach Hope Gently
bullets: Say: “We miss them and we will still be okay.”
Make a small future plan with your child (outing, holiday plan, weekend activity).
Tell one story of resilience from your family or faith history.
Create one “hope tradition” (weekly walk, scripture reading, gratitude jar).
Repeat the phrase: “God is with us, even here.”

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Children borrow hope from adults.

Your steady words become their future confidence.

completionCard.title: Journey complete
completionCard.message: You opened your heart with wisdom and gentleness.

journeys.title: Dating After Loss with Wisdom
journeys.summary: Activities to date safely, protect your heart and home, and move slowly with calm confidence.

milestones.title: Halfway through
milestones.message: You are becoming stronger and steadier.

missions.title: Release the Guilt of Living
missions.subtitle: Living Again Is Not Betrayal.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Many widowed people feel guilt when they laugh again, enjoy company, or consider love.

But guilt is not honor. Right now you’ll release false guilt and allow your heart to heal.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You can honor your spouse and still live.

Grief and joy can exist in the same heart.

cards.title: Choose Your Guilt Thought
cards.prompt: Which thought shows up when you feel a little joy?
options: It feels wrong to be happy.
It means I didn’t love them enough.
It feels like leaving them behind.

cards.title: Replace Guilt with Truth
bullets: Journal  the guilt sentence exactly as it comes.
Complete  a truth sentence: “My joy does not erase my love.”
Journal  one honor action: speak their name, thank God for them, or care for something they valued.
Write  one living action: meet a friend, go outside, do something that brings calm joy.
Finish with: “I can honor love and still live.”

cards.title: A Wiser Lens
cards.text:
Honor is not staying stuck. Honor is carrying love with dignity while you steward the life God still gave you. a small example: when the quiet feels loud, choose one small action instead of scrolling for hours.

That is how you protect your heart.

A widow said, “The first time I laughed with someone, guilt hit me immediately.” She learned to say, “This joy does not erase my love.” That sentence helped her breathe again.

missions.title: Release the Guilt of Living
missions.subtitle: Joy, Companionship, and Love Are Not Betrayal.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Many widowed people feel guilt when they start enjoying life again. Guilt can show up as fear of judgment, fear of disappointing family, or fear that God is displeased.

Today you will release guilt with truth and honor.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text: Your spouse’s love is not proven by your sadness. Love is proven by the life you shared and the way you honor it.

cards.title: Choose Your Guilt Voice
cards.prompt: When you feel joy or interest in someone new, what does guilt say?
options: It means I didn’t love my spouse enough.
God will be disappointed in me.

cards.title: Do the Guilt Release Script
bullets: Write the guilt sentence exactly.
Write a truth sentence beside it (example: “Joy does not erase love.”).
Write one honor act you already do (prayer, remembrance, integrity).
Write one living act you want to allow (friendship, laughter, community).
Say out loud: “I can honor love and still live.”
Repeat daily for 7 days.

cards.title: A Small Story
cards.text: A widow said, “The first time I laughed with someone, guilt hit me immediately.” She learned to say, “This joy does not erase my love.” That sentence helped her breathe again.

missions.title: Know Your Readiness Signs
missions.subtitle: Readiness Is More Than Loneliness.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Loneliness can make you rush.

Fear can make you avoid. Today you will identify readiness signs so you move with wisdom and protect your heart.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text: Readiness is not perfection. It is emotional stability, clarity, and the ability to move without desperation.

cards.title: Choose Where You Are Right Now
cards.prompt: Which statement fits you best?
options: I’m lonely and tempted to rush.
I want companionship but I’m afraid.
I’m ready to build friendship first.
I feel pressured by others to move on.

cards.title: Do the Readiness Check
bullets: Rate 1-10: emotional stability, loneliness, fear, clarity.
Write: “My biggest reason for considering love again is…”
Write: “My biggest risk if I rush is…”
Choose a pace statement: “I will move slowly and learn first.”
Pick one next step that matches your pace: friendship, mentoring, group settings, or rest.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Loneliness is not a guide.

Wisdom is. Move in ways that protect your heart and honor your life.

missions.title: Set Clear Boundaries Early
missions.subtitle: Boundaries Protect Dignity and Clarity.
missions.whyThisMatters: When you start talking to someone, emotions can rise quickly. Without boundaries, you can feel confused, guilty, or overwhelmed. Today you will set boundaries that are clear, respectful, and faith-aligned.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Boundaries are not walls.

They are guardrails. They keep you from falling into regret or confusion.

cards.title: Choose Your Boundary Weakness
cards.prompt: Which area do you struggle to set boundaries in?

cards.title: Write Your Boundary Lines
bullets: Write 3 boundaries you want to keep.
Turn each one into a sentence you can say.
Examples: “I move slowly.” “I don’t do late-night conversations.” “I don’t borrow or lend money.”
Practice saying them out loud once.
If the person reacts badly, take it as information, not drama.

cards.title: Keep This in Mind
cards.text: Respectful people respect boundaries. People who resist your boundaries often want access, not covenant.

missions.title: Protect Your Heart from Fantasy
missions.subtitle: After Loss, Attention Can Feel Like Oxygen.
missions.whyThisMatters:
After grief, attention can feel deeply soothing. But fantasy can grow quickly: imagining marriage, imagining safety, imagining a future with someone you barely know.

Today you will stay grounded and move slowly.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Your heart deserves reality, not fantasy.

Fantasy is comforting, but it can lead to heartbreak.

cards.title: Choose Your Fantasy Trigger
cards.prompt: What triggers fantasy for you most?
options: They say kind words and I attach quickly.
They give me attention and I feel chosen.
They remind me of my spouse.
I feel lonely and imagine a whole future.

cards.title: Do the Reality Anchor
bullets: Write: “What I know about them is…” (facts only).
Write: “What I’m imagining is…”
Write: “What I need to learn before I attach is…”
Choose one boundary that slows the pace (group settings, limited calls).
End with: “I choose wisdom over fantasy.”

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text:
Fantasy often grows where grief is still hungry.

Reality protects you from making love a bandage.

missions.title: Handle Family Pressure
missions.subtitle: Pressure Makes Love Feel Unsafe.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Some families pressure widowed people to remarry quickly.

Others pressure them to never remarry. Both extremes are harmful. Today you will respond to pressure with calm, clear boundaries.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Your life belongs to God and you.

Family opinions can be loud, but they are not your compass.

cards.title: Choose the Pressure You Face
cards.prompt: Which pressure do you face most?
options: Pressure to choose a specific person

cards.title: Write Your Pressure Boundary
bullets: Write one sentence: “My pace is…”
Write one sentence you will tell family: “I appreciate your concern. I’m moving slowly and prayerfully.”
Write one consequence: “If pressure continues, I will end the conversation.”
Practice saying your boundary out loud.
If pressure is heavy, ask one trusted person to support you in family spaces.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Pressure is often about other people’s discomfort, not your readiness.

You are allowed to protect your pace.

missions.title: Choose Friendship First
missions.subtitle: Friendship Reveals Character over Time.
missions.whyThisMatters:
A healthy relationship after loss needs a foundation stronger than chemistry or loneliness. Friendship allows you to observe consistency, maturity, and kindness.

Today you will build friendship with wisdom.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text: Friendship slows the pace. It protects you from attaching to a version of someone you haven’t tested.

cards.title: Choose What You Need to Observe
cards.prompt: What do you need to observe before you attach deeply?

cards.title: The Friendship Test
bullets: Spend time in group settings first.
Ask one meaningful question: “How do you handle stress and conflict?”
Notice whether their words match their actions.
Keep your boundaries for 4 weeks.
After 4 weeks, journal: “What have I learned about their character?”

cards.title: Keep This in Mind
cards.text:
Chemistry can be instant.

Character is revealed over time. Protect your heart with patience.

missions.title: Talk to God About Love Again
missions.subtitle: God Cares About Your Heart and Your Future.
missions.whyThisMatters: Many widowed people feel confused: is dating allowed, is it sinful, will God bless it, what does honoring my spouse look like? Today you will pray with clarity and ask for God’s guidance without shame.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
God is not surprised by your desire for companionship.

Bring it to Him honestly.

cards.title: Choose Your Spiritual Question
cards.prompt: Which question is strongest for you?
options: Is it okay to love again?
How do I honor my spouse while dating?
How do I know if someone is God’s will?
What if I love again and lose again?

cards.title: Pray with Clarity
bullets: Write your question to God in one sentence.
Read 1 Corinthians 13: 4-7 and underline the qualities of love.
Write what kind of love you want to build (patient, kind, respectful).
Ask God for one clear sign of wisdom: peace, clarity, counsel, or delay.
End with: “God, guide me. I will not rush.”

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text:
Peace is not excitement.

Peace is steadiness. God often leads through calm clarity, not pressure.

missions.title: Protect Your Children Emotionally
missions.subtitle: Your Children Need Safety, Not Secrets.
missions.whyThisMatters: If you have children, dating can trigger fear and insecurity. Today you will protect your children emotionally: no rushing introductions, no confusion, no emotional burden on them.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Your children don’t need to be involved early.

They need stability and reassurance.

cards.title: Choose Your Child Concern
cards.prompt: What concern do you have most about dating with children?
options: They will resent a new person

cards.title: Use the Child Safety Plan
bullets: Do not introduce anyone quickly.
Keep dating private until it is serious and stable.
When the time comes, introduce slowly in group settings.
Reassure your child: “No one replaces your parent.”
Watch your child’s behavior for stress signs and respond gently.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Children feel safe when they see you steady and consistent.

Do not let dating create emotional instability at home.

missions.title: Choose a Wise Mentor
missions.subtitle: You Should Not Navigate Love Alone.
missions.whyThisMatters: After loss, your heart is tender and your judgment can be affected by loneliness, fear, or guilt. A wise mentor helps you see clearly and stay aligned with your values.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
A mentor is not there to control you.

They are there to help you move with wisdom and integrity.

cards.title: Choose the Mentor Type
cards.prompt: Who could be a wise mentor for you?
options: A family elder who respects my pace

cards.title: Set up Mentorship
bullets: Choose one person and ask: “Can I check in with you as I navigate this?”
Share your boundaries and values with them.
Agree on a check-in frequency (weekly or biweekly).
When you feel confused, bring the situation to them early, not late.
Write: “Wise counsel protects my heart.”

cards.title: A Calm Note
cards.text:
Isolation makes you vulnerable to impulsive decisions.

Mentorship protects you from regret.

completionCard.title: Journey complete
completionCard.message: You practiced dating after loss with wisdom.

journeys.title: Blending Memories and New Beginnings
journeys.summary: Activities to hold your past with honor while building a new chapter with peace and wisdom.

milestones.title: Halfway through
milestones.message: You are learning to hold memories and new beginnings with peace.

missions.title: Name What Still Matters
missions.subtitle:
Purpose Doesn’t Disappear.

It Gets Reshaped.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Loss can make life feel like it lost meaning.

But purpose is not only tied to a person. In this session you will name what still matters, so you can begin building forward again.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Your future does not have to look like the past.

But it can still be meaningful. This time you’ll start rebuilding purpose with honesty.

cards.title: Choose What Still Matters
cards.prompt: Which value still matters deeply to you?

cards.title: Write Your Purpose Anchor
bullets: Finish: “What still matters to me is ______.”
Finish: “I want my life to stand for ______.”
Choose one small action that reflects this value this week.
Schedule it on your calendar.
Finish with: “My life still has meaning.”

cards.title: What This Changes
cards.text:
Purpose doesn’t arrive as a feeling.

It grows as you take steps that match your values. example: when your chest tightens after a memory, pause, breathe out slowly, and do one grounding act.

This is how you stay steady.

missions.title: Create a Memory Space
missions.subtitle: Memories Need a Home so They Don’t Haunt Every Corner.
missions.whyThisMatters: When everything in the house feels like a reminder, grief becomes constant. Today you will create one memory space where you can remember with honor, and also create other spaces that support daily life.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text: You are not asked to erase. You are invited to organize your memories so your home can feel livable again.

cards.title: Choose What Feels Hardest in Your Space
cards.prompt: What makes your home emotionally heavy right now?
options: Their belongings are everywhere and I feel overwhelmed.
Photos are painful but I don’t want to remove them.
I avoid parts of the house.
The home feels empty and cold.

cards.title: Create One Memory Space
bullets: Choose one small spot: a shelf, a drawer, a corner table.
Place 3-5 meaningful items there (photo, letter, small object).
Light a candle or say a short prayer there once a week.
Choose one room you want to make more livable and change one thing (move furniture, add light, add music).
Write: “This home can hold memory and life.”

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text: When memories are everywhere, they feel like constant pain. When memories have a place, they become honor instead of ambush.

missions.title: Sort Belongings with Wisdom
missions.subtitle: Sorting Is Emotional Work, Not Only Practical Work.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Belongings carry scent, history, and identity.

Sorting them can feel like betrayal. But leaving everything untouched can keep you stuck. Today you will sort with wisdom and a pace that honors your heart.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text: You do not need to sort everything at once. You need a system that respects grief and still creates progress.

cards.title: Choose What Makes Sorting Hardest
cards.prompt: What is hardest about sorting belongings?
options: I feel overwhelmed and don’t know where to start.
I’m afraid I’ll regret what I give away.
I’m afraid of breaking down emotionally.

cards.title: Use the 4-box Method
bullets: Set a timer for 25 minutes.
Prepare 4 boxes: KEEP, GIVE, STORE, DECIDE LATER.
Choose one small category: shoes, books, shirts, documents.
Sort quickly without overthinking. Put heavy items in DECIDE LATER.
Stop when the timer ends. Do not push beyond your capacity.
After, do one comfort action: tea, shower, worship music, or calling someone.

cards.title: A Small Story
cards.text:
One widower said he couldn’t touch his wife’s clothes for a year.

He started with one drawer, then stopped. That small step was enough.

Healing is not speed. Healing is movement.

missions.title: Prepare for Anniversary Dates
missions.subtitle: Dates Can Hit You Harder Than You Expect.
missions.whyThisMatters: Anniversaries, holidays, and the day of loss can bring intense grief. Today you will plan ahead so the date doesn’t destroy you emotionally.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Planning doesn’t remove grief.

It reduces panic. You deserve support on hard dates.

cards.title: Choose Your Upcoming Date
cards.prompt: Which date is coming soon?

cards.title: Make the Date Plan
bullets: Write the date and how you usually feel around it.
Choose one honor act (visit, prayer, memory sharing, candle).
Choose one support act (friend visit, family dinner, church support).
Choose one comfort act (rest, meal, music, quiet time).
Plan what you will avoid if needed (crowds, social media).
After the date, schedule one gentle recovery day.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Hard dates don’t mean you are going backward.

They mean love was real. Planning helps you hold love with dignity.

missions.title: Handle Sudden Triggers in Public
missions.subtitle: You Can Be Triggered Anywhere, and You Need a Plan.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Grief can hit you in a supermarket, church, or event.

When it happens, you may feel embarrassed or unsafe. Today you will create a public trigger plan so you can recover quickly without shame.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Being triggered in public is not weakness.

It is grief. Preparation gives you confidence.

cards.title: Choose Your Public Trigger
cards.prompt: Where do triggers hit you most often?

cards.title: Create Your Public Plan
bullets: Choose one exit plan: bathroom break, outside air, short walk.
Choose one grounding tool: cold water, breath out for 6, hand on chest.
Choose one sentence you can tell yourself: “This is grief. I am safe.”
Choose one person you can text quickly: “Hard moment. Please pray.”
After you leave, do one calming action and return only if you want to.

cards.title: Keep This in Mind
cards.text:
You don’t need to be fearless.

You need a plan that keeps you safe and dignified.

missions.title: Let Yourself Dream Again
missions.subtitle:
Dreaming Is Not Betrayal.

It Is Courage.
missions.whyThisMatters:
After loss, dreaming can feel dangerous.

You may fear disappointment or guilt. But the future still matters.

Today you will allow small dreams again without pressure.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Dreaming is not pretending the past did not happen.

Dreaming is believing God can still write new chapters.

cards.title: Choose What Dreaming Triggers
cards.prompt: What makes dreaming hard for you?
options: Feeling like my future is empty

cards.title: Create a Small Dream List
bullets: Write 5 small dreams that are not huge or dramatic (travel, hobby, friendship, ministry, health).
Circle one dream you can act on this month.
Break it into 3 steps and schedule step 1.
Tell one safe person about the dream.
Write: “My life can still grow.”

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text:
Many people don’t fail because they dream.

They fail because they stop dreaming. God can meet you in your next chapter.

missions.title: Create New Traditions
missions.subtitle: Traditions Help Your Heart Adjust.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Some traditions will always hurt.

But new traditions can help you live again. Today you will create a new tradition that supports healing and honors memory.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
New traditions don’t erase old ones.

They help your heart breathe again.

cards.title: Choose the Tradition You Want to Reshape
cards.prompt: Which tradition feels hardest now?

cards.title: Build One New Tradition
bullets: Choose one tradition and change one part of it.
Example: invite someone, change location, add a prayer moment, simplify it.
Write: “The new version of this tradition will be…”
Try it once within the next month.
Afterward, journal: “What helped? What hurt? What I will keep is…”

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text: Traditions shape the nervous system. New traditions teach your heart that life still continues safely.

missions.title: Carry Their Memory with Peace
missions.subtitle: Honor Doesn’t Require Constant Pain.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Some people feel like remembering must always hurt.

But memory can become peaceful over time. Today you will choose a memory practice that brings gratitude without dragging you into constant sadness.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Honoring memory is not staying in pain.

It is carrying love with gratitude and dignity.

cards.title: Choose Your Memory Struggle
cards.prompt: What makes memory difficult right now?
options: Memories make me feel stuck in the past.

cards.title: Create a Memory Practice
bullets: Pick one memory you appreciate.
Write 3 sentences: “What I loved… What I learned… What I carry forward…”
Pray one line of gratitude.
Stop after 5 minutes. Don’t push beyond your capacity.
Do this once a week, not daily.

cards.title: A Calm Note
cards.text:
Gratitude softens memory.

It turns remembering into honor, not torture.

missions.title: Balance Grief and Growth
missions.subtitle:
Growth Is Not Replacing Grief.

It Is Carrying It Well.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Some people fear growth because they think it dishonors grief.

Others rush growth to avoid pain. Today you will balance grief and growth in a healthy way.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Healthy healing includes both grief and growth.

You don’t need to choose one.

cards.title: Choose Your Imbalance
cards.prompt: Which imbalance do you struggle with most?
options: I stay stuck in grief and avoid life.
I try to be strong and avoid grief.
I grow in some ways but feel guilty.
I want to grow but don’t know how.

cards.title: Create Your Balance Plan
bullets: Write one grief practice you will keep (journaling, prayer, memory time).
Write one growth practice you will build (exercise, friendship, skill).
Schedule both in your week.
At the end of the week, ask: “Did I honor grief and also honor life?”
Adjust gently, not harshly.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Balance is not perfect.

Balance is paying attention and adjusting with compassion.

missions.title: Build Your Hope Board
missions.subtitle: Visual Hope Helps Your Brain Believe Again.
missions.whyThisMatters:
When grief is strong, the future feels invisible.

A hope board helps you see possibility. Today you will create a hope board that includes faith, goals, and small joys.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
This is not pretending.

This is training your mind to see possibility again.

cards.title: Choose What Your Hope Board Should Include
cards.prompt: What do you want your hope board to focus on?

cards.title: Create Your Hope Board
bullets: Use paper or your phone.
Add 5 images or words that represent your future.
Add one verse (Isaiah 43: 19 or Jeremiah 29:11).
Place it somewhere you will see daily.
Each morning, say: “God can still write new chapters.”
Choose one small action from the board this week.

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text:
Hope is not only spiritual.

It is also practical. When you see your future, you start building it.

completionCard.title: Journey complete
completionCard.message: You practiced blending memories and new beginnings with peace.

journeys.title: Preparing for a New Covenant
journeys.summary: Activities to prepare your heart, clarify your values, and enter a new marriage with wisdom and peace.

milestones.title: Halfway through
milestones.message: You are preparing your heart for a new chapter with faith and wisdom.

missions.title: Check Your Readiness
missions.subtitle: Readiness Is Capacity, Not Loneliness.
missions.whyThisMatters: Widowed people can feel ready because they miss companionship, but readiness is about emotional stability and wisdom. Here you’ll check your readiness so you don’t enter love to escape grief.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text: You don’t need to be “over it.” You need to be steady enough to love without using love as a bandage.

cards.title: Choose Your Biggest Risk
cards.prompt: If you entered a relationship too early, what is most likely to happen?
options: I would cling because I’m lonely.
I would compare them to my spouse.
I would avoid conflict and stay silent.
I would panic when I feel unsafe.
I would rush intimacy to feel secure.

cards.title: Your Readiness Check
bullets: Rate 1 to 10:
I can be alone without panic.
I can handle conflict calmly.
I can set boundaries without guilt.
I can enjoy love without fear leading me.
Circle the lowest score and write: “This is where I’m still healing.” Pick one step to strengthen this area this week.

cards.title: A Quick Truth
cards.text:
You are not wrong for wanting love again.

But love must be chosen with wisdom, not desperation.

Here’s what it can look like: when your chest tightens after a memory, pause, breathe out slowly, and do one grounding act.

This is how you stay steady.

missions.title: Notice What’s Keeping You Stuck
missions.subtitle: Stuck Grief Needs Extra Care, Not Shame.
missions.whyThisMatters: Long-term grief can sometimes become complicated: not because you’re weak, but because pain has layered effects. Today you will notice what might be keeping you stuck so you can seek the right support and move forward wisely.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Grief has no deadline.

But you deserve progress. Not by forcing yourself, but by identifying what needs attention.

cards.title: Choose Your Stuck Sign
cards.prompt: Which sign feels most true for you?
options: I avoid anything that reminds me of them.
I feel intense bitterness or anger most days.
I feel numb and disconnected for long periods.
I feel guilty anytime I try to live.
I feel like I can’t imagine a future at all.

cards.title: Do the Stuck Inventory
bullets: Write the stuck sign you chose.
Write: “What I fear will happen if I heal is…”
Write: “What I fear will happen if I don’t heal is…”
Circle the fear that feels strongest.
Choose one support step: trusted mentor, grief group, or professional support.
Schedule the support step this week.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Getting support is not a sign of failure.

It is a sign of wisdom. You were never meant to carry deep grief alone.

missions.title: Know When You Need Extra Support
missions.subtitle: Some Grief Requires Outside Help to Protect Your Life.
missions.whyThisMatters: There are moments when grief moves beyond normal pain into something that can threaten your health, safety, or ability to function. Today you will identify when you should seek extra support and what kind of support to seek.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Support is not about labels.

It is about protection. God often heals through people and wise help.

cards.title: Choose What You’re Noticing
cards.prompt: Which situation is closest to you?
options: I can function but I feel overwhelmed often.
I feel stuck and nothing seems to help.
My sleep and appetite are severely affected.
I am isolating and losing interest in life.
I’m having thoughts that scare me.

cards.title: Take the Right Step
bullets: If you are having thoughts of harming yourself or you feel unsafe, contact emergency support immediately or reach out to a trusted person right now.
If your sleep, appetite, or functioning is severely affected, seek professional support this week.
If you feel stuck, join a grief support group or talk to a trusted guide.
If you feel overwhelmed, schedule one weekly check-in with a safe person.
Write one sentence: “I deserve help. I deserve healing.”

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text: Strong people still need help. Seeking support is one of the most courageous decisions you can make.

completionCard.title: You released fear
completionCard.message: That step made your heart lighter.

missions.title: Rebuild Your Body’s Strength
missions.subtitle: Healing Includes Your Body, Not Only Your Emotions.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Grief lives in the body.

It affects appetite, sleep, energy, and immunity. Today you will rebuild strength through simple body care habits so you feel steadier over time.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text: You don’t need intense fitness. You need consistent care that restores energy and reduces emotional overwhelm.

cards.title: Choose the Weakest Area
cards.prompt: Which area needs the most attention right now?

cards.title: Do the Body Care Plan
bullets: Pick one area and choose one habit to improve this week.
Examples: sleep by 10pm twice, eat one full meal daily, walk 15 minutes, drink 2 bottles of water.
Write the habit and schedule it.
Track it for 7 days.
After 7 days, add one more small habit.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
When your body is stronger, your emotions feel more manageable.

Body care is a grief skill.

missions.title: Rebuild Meaning in Your Life
missions.subtitle: Meaning Is What Keeps Grief from Becoming Hopeless.
missions.whyThisMatters: After loss, life can feel meaningless. Many widowed people ask, “What is the point now?” Today you will rebuild meaning through values, service, faith, and community.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Meaning doesn’t come from forcing happiness.

It comes from living in alignment with what matters.

cards.title: Choose Your Meaning Source
cards.prompt: Which source of meaning feels strongest for you?

cards.title: Create a Meaning Action
bullets: Write: “My life still matters because…”
Write one value you want to live by.
Choose one action this week that reflects that value.
Schedule it.
After, journal: “What did this awaken in me?”

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text:
Meaning is not found by thinking alone.

Meaning grows through action.

completionCard.title: You created a plan
completionCard.message: A plan protects love in hard moments.

missions.title: Create a Long-term Healing Plan
missions.subtitle: Healing Needs Direction, Not Pressure.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Without a plan, grief can become repetitive and stagnant.

With a plan, you can still grieve while building a life. Today you will set a 6-month healing plan that is realistic and gentle.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
A healing plan is not a deadline.

It is a direction. It helps you move with intention.

cards.title: Choose Your Next 6-month Focus
cards.prompt: Which focus would help you most?

cards.title: Build Your 6-month Plan
bullets: Write your chosen focus at the top.
Break it into 3 stages: Month 1-2, Month 3-4, Month 5-6.
For each stage, write one key action.
Choose one action to begin this week.
Review your plan monthly and adjust gently.

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Healing is not a single decision.

It is consistent direction over time.

missions.title: Let Yourself Love Again in New Forms
missions.subtitle:
Love Doesn’t End.

It Changes Shape.
missions.whyThisMatters: You may feel love for your spouse and still love friends, children, community, or even a future partner. Today you will expand love without guilt and without confusion.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
God created you for connection.

Love can widen without replacing what you had.

cards.title: Choose What Love Feels Hard About
cards.prompt: What makes love after loss difficult?

cards.title: Expand Love Intentionally
bullets: Write: “Love for my spouse means…”
Write: “Love for my life now means…”
Choose one connection action: deepen friendship, join community, mentor someone, or date slowly.
Pray: “God, teach me love that honors the past and welcomes the present.”
Repeat weekly for one month.

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text:
Loyalty is not staying lonely.

Loyalty is carrying love with integrity.

missions.title: Forgive Yourself for Surviving
missions.subtitle: Survivor Guilt Is Real and Heavy.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Some widowed people feel guilty for being alive.

They feel guilty when they laugh, succeed, or enjoy life. Today you will release survivor guilt and accept God’s permission to live fully.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
You did not choose this loss.

You are allowed to live. You are allowed to breathe.

You are allowed to heal.

cards.title: Choose Your Survivor Guilt Thought
cards.prompt: Which thought hits you most often?
options: Why am I still here and they are not?
It feels wrong to feel okay.
If I heal, it means I forgot them.

cards.title: Do the Survivor Guilt Release
bullets: Write the guilt thought exactly.
Write one truth sentence: “My survival is not a sin.”
Write one honor action that proves love (memory, integrity, prayer).
Write one living action you will allow this week (joy, rest, community).
Speak: “God gave me life. I will steward it.”

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Survivor guilt keeps you trapped in a false debt.

Mercy is the way out.

missions.title: Rebuild Confidence in Relationships
missions.subtitle: Loss Can Make You Fear Attachment.
missions.whyThisMatters:
After losing someone, you may fear closeness because it feels unsafe.

You may also cling tightly because you fear being alone. Today you will rebuild healthy attachment with wisdom.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Healthy relationships require safety, boundaries, and trust.

You can build these again.

cards.title: Choose Your Relationship Pattern
cards.prompt: Which pattern do you notice in yourself?
options: I avoid closeness because it feels risky.
I cling to people because I fear losing them.
I feel emotionally numb around people.

cards.title: Practice Secure Connection
bullets: Choose one safe person.
Share one honest feeling this week without over-explaining.
Practice one boundary: limit calls, say no, or ask for space.
Notice how they respond to your honesty and boundaries.
Write: “Safe people respond with respect, not pressure.”

cards.title: A True Thing
cards.text:
Healing attachment takes practice.

Start with safe people and small vulnerability.

missions.title: Live with Purpose Again
missions.subtitle: Purpose Keeps You from Living Only in Grief.
missions.whyThisMatters:
Your life can still bless others.

Purpose does not erase pain. It gives your pain somewhere to go. Today you will choose one purpose action that aligns with your faith and values.

cards.title: Start Here
cards.text:
Purpose is not only big projects.

Purpose is consistent contribution, even in small ways.

cards.title: Choose Your Purpose Lane
cards.prompt: Which lane fits you best right now?
options: Building a stable home for my children

cards.title: Do the Purpose Step
bullets: Choose one lane and write one action you can do this month.
Make it small and realistic.
Schedule it.
Tell one trusted person so you follow through.
After you do it, journal: “What did I feel and learn?”

cards.title: Remember This
cards.text:
Purpose doesn’t always feel exciting at first.

It feels meaningful. Over time, meaning becomes strength.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text:
Lord, use my life again.

Give me purpose that honors my past and blesses my future. Amen.
